dt: {bc}foretell on the basis of observation, experience, or scientific reason

pt: {sc}foretell{/sc} {sc}predict{/sc} {sc}forecast{/sc} {sc}prophesy{/sc} {sc}prognosticate{/sc} mean to tell beforehand. {sc}foretell{/sc} applies to the telling of the coming of a future event by any procedure or any source of information.
{sc}predict{/sc} commonly implies inference from facts or accepted laws of nature.
{sc}forecast{/sc} adds the implication of anticipating eventualities and differs from {sc}predict{/sc} in being usually concerned with probabilities rather than certainties.
{sc}prophesy{/sc} connotes inspired or mystic knowledge of the future especially as the fulfilling of divine threats or promises.

{sc}prognosticate{/sc} is used less often than the other words; it may suggest learned or skilled interpretation, but more often it is simply a colorful substitute for {sc}predict{/sc} or {sc}prophesy{/sc}.

et: Latin {it}praedictus{/it}, past participle of {it}praedicere{/it}, from {it}prae-{/it} pre- + {it}dicere{/it} to say {ma}{mat|diction|}{/ma}
shortdef: to declare or indicate in advance; especially : foretell on the basis of observation, experience, or scientific reason
